data.title: underrated/obscure 60's classics?
data.meta_description:
hi,
 lately i've been discovering some great 60's music from bands i have never heard of. this search started a while back, after i listened to love's...
data.text:
Mar 27, 2004 at 6:35 PM Thread Starter Post #1 of 9

dougbrad81

100+ Head-Fier

Joined

Jul 23, 2002

Posts

377

Likes

10

hi,

lately i've been discovering some great 60's music from bands i have never heard of. this search started a while back, after i listened to love's forever changes, pretty things S.F sorrow, and the zombies odyssey and oracle; three great 60's albums that seems to have finally gotten the recognition it deserve after all these years. so i search for more bands that hasn't yet enjoyed a resurgence in intrest. so far i have found three great ones:

The Smoke - The Smoke

The End - Introspection

Millenium - Magic Time: The Millennium/Ballroom Sessions

all three seems heavily influenced by pet sounds, bit still a great listen nonetheless. anybody else have discovered some great obscure 60's music?

I live in the midrange!

I don't know their work well enough to recommend an album, but the 13th Floor Elevators are worth giving a listen to.

A not so obvious pick - The Hollies

Mar 27, 2004 at 7:55 PM Post #3 of 9

Lots of very cool hard rocking garage & psychedellic stuff from the 1960's, problem is the sound quality is often not very good

There are some good multi CD sets like the Rhino Records "nuggets" collection of psychedellic music, this has the bigger name bands you will recognize like:

blues magoos

count five

sonics

standells

shadows of the night

electric prunes

kingsmen

etc etc.

More obscure groups are found on "pebbles" CD collections but here sound quality goes down usually because master tapes are gone and CD uses best vinyl record they can find and record from that for CD, so you hear some record pops/surface noise

Then there are really obscure 60's garage band collections that rox your sox but sound quality is poor, like record from slavation army was used for CD, he he. One series I have here is called "back from the grave" just amazing how these small unknown bands can flat out rock

Mar 28, 2004 at 8:55 AM Post #4 of 9

servoled

Joined

I'd agree that the Nuggets box sets are a great place to start. Another series is the Teenage Shutdown series. If your interested in finding more bands I highly reccomend listening to the following radio shows from WFMU:

Dave the Spazz - Music to Spazz By

Billy Kelly - Teenage Wasteland

Both shows are broadcast weekly in real audio and streaming mp3 and play a fair amount of 60's music. Dave the Spazz plays more rockabilly, r&b, blues, soul, and rock while Bill Kelly plays more straight up garage rock or as he says "Real Rock n' Roll". There are also archives in real audio format and playlists going back to sometime in 2000 for both shows so you can listen whenever you want.

I went through a big phase of buying up obscure 60's stuff. A few highlights...

Thirteenth Floor Elevators - Easter Everywhere

The United States of America - S/T

Monks - Black Monk Time

Spirit - 12 Dreams of Dr. Sardonicus

The Move - Omnibus (a singles comp.)

Moby Grape - S/T and 1969

And I definitely agree that the Nuggets sets are well worth picking up.
